Sawers</span></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-8 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11 ArticleContent_mck-c-article-content__share-tools__kWRRw"></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-animation-blur-in-400"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-5"><div class="mck-u-links-inline">It’s time for the apparel industry to radically reduce the industry’s contribution to biodiversity loss. Here are four interventions that can make the biggest impact.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fretail%2Four%20insights%2Fbiodiversity%20the%20next%20frontier%20in%20sustainable%20fashion%2Fbiodiversity-the-next-frontier-in-sustainable-fashion-v3.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="biodiversity-the-next-frontier-in-sustainable-fashion-v3" data-layer-report-name="biodiversity-the-next-frontier-in-sustainable-fashion-v3>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (9 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Even amid the COVID-19 pandemic,</strong> sustainability remains top of mind for consumers, investors, and regulators—in fact, engagement in sustainability has deepened during the crisis. For example, two-thirds of apparel shoppers say that limiting impact on climate change is now more important to them since before COVID-19.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c02c01a7-7b21-4734-a192-3ab6f1387c79"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c02c01a7-7b21-4734-a192-3ab6f1387c79" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Consumer sentiment on sustainability and fashion in the COVID crisis,” May 2020, McKinsey.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<!-- -->
<p>But while much has been written about <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/survey-consumer-sentiment-on-sustainability-in-fashion">the fashion industry’s impact on climate change</a>, less well known and well covered is the industry’s heavy footprint on biodiversity. Broadly defined as the variety of all life forms on earth, biodiversity matters. We rely on it for food and energy, and we depend on its irreplaceable role in sustaining air quality, providing fresh water and soil, and regulating climate. And yet biodiversity is declining at a faster rate than ever before in human history.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="45ef5c0f-9fde-4a44-89ae-bb53836719d0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="45ef5c0f-9fde-4a44-89ae-bb53836719d0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>IPBES 2019 Global assessment report on biodiversity and ecosystem services</em>, Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services, May 2019, ipbes.net.</span></span></span></a></span> One million species, between 12 percent and 20 percent of estimated total species, marine and terrestrial alike, are under threat of extinction.</p>
<p>The apparel industry is a significant contributor to biodiversity loss. Apparel supply chains are directly linked to soil degradation, conversion of natural ecosystems, and waterway pollution.</p>
<p>This article examines the apparel industry’s largest contributors to biodiversity loss, how companies can strategically mitigate that loss, and what brands can do to boldly lead the industry’s biodiversity efforts.</p>
<h2>Apparel’s contribution to biodiversity loss</h2>
<p>For several years now, apparel companies have been active in the fight against climate change, launching myriad initiatives to become carbon neutral. Biodiversity is a distinct but related issue. Biodiversity loss and climate change are interdependent and mutually reinforcing—one accelerates the other, and vice versa. For example, protecting forests could help reduce greenhouse-gas emissions. In turn, the rise of global temperatures increases the risk of species extinction.</p>
<p>Because biodiversity is such a complex and multidimensional landscape, and ecosystem degradation is so wide ranging—affecting oceans, freshwater, soil, and forests—multiple metrics and indicators are needed to measure impact and progress. Setting targets and accountability for such a complex range is much more challenging than managing for the single metric of greenhouse emissions.</p>
<p>Through our analysis of quantitative impact indicators as well as industry-expert interviews, we have developed a good understanding of how each part of the apparel value chain affects biodiversity. Most of the negative impact comes from three stages in the <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/what-radical-transparency-could-mean-for-the-fashion-industry">value chain</a>: raw-material production, material preparation and processing, and end of life (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/retail/our%20insights/biodiversity%20the%20next%20frontier%20in%20sustainable%20fashion/svgz-biodiversity-the-next-frontier-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Most of the negative impact on biodiversity comes from raw-material production, material preparation and processing, and end of life." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/retail/our%20insights/biodiversity%20the%20next%20frontier%20in%20sustainable%20fashion/svgz-biodiversity-the-next-frontier-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>We also have developed a map of biodiversity impact areas to help companies determine where to focus their efforts (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/retail/our%20insights/biodiversity%20the%20next%20frontier%20in%20sustainable%20fashion/svgz-biodiversity-the-next-frontier-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="A map of biodiversity impact areas can help companies determine where to focus their efforts." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/retail/our%20insights/biodiversity%20the%20next%20frontier%20in%20sustainable%20fashion/svgz-biodiversity-the-next-frontier-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Based on our analysis, we have identified the apparel sector’s five largest contributors to biodiversity loss. They are presented according to the fashion value chain, not by magnitude of impact:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Cotton agriculture.</em> Cotton is the most used nonsynthetic fiber in the world. Farming it is especially insecticide and pesticide intensive: although cotton grows on only 2.4 percent of global cropland, it accounts for 22.5 percent of the world’s insecticide use—more than any other single crop—and 10 percent of all pesticide use. Cotton is also a water-intensive crop; some estimates suggest that 713 gallons (2,700 liters) of water are needed to produce one T-shirt.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="90ec1a75-c5b6-4557-bc10-80f775b779f8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="90ec1a75-c5b6-4557-bc10-80f775b779f8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Handle with Care: Understanding the hidden environmental costs of cotton,” <em>World Wildlife Magazine</em>, Spring 2014, worldwildlife.org.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Wood-based natural fibers/man-made cellulose fibers (MMCFs).</em> MMCFs are created from cellulose, mainly derived from wood. According to estimates, more than 150 million trees are logged annually for MMCFs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8790d360-79c8-4d30-b066-b6e4ecf8f9b8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8790d360-79c8-4d30-b066-b6e4ecf8f9b8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“CanopyStyle,” Canopy, 2020, canopyplanet.org.</span></span></span></a></span> While the majority of MMCFs come from tree plantations that are certified and sustainable, up to 30 percent of MMCFs may come from endangered and primary forests.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c2347b73-c74b-4010-ba98-67f36e30d43f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c2347b73-c74b-4010-ba98-67f36e30d43f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">D.G. McCullough, “Deforestation for fashion: Getting unsustainable fabrics out of the closet,” <em>Guardian</em>, April 25, 2014, theguardian.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Furthermore, water and soil pollution from chemicals used in plantation forests and during pulp processing drive habitat loss and endanger species, unless the process is 100 percent closed loop.</li>
    <li><em>Textile dyeing and treatment.</em> Approximately 25 percent of industrial water pollution comes from textile dyeing and treatment. These processes overexploit freshwater resources and contaminate waterways through chemical runoff and nonbiodegradable liquid waste. Of the 1,900 chemicals used in clothing production, the European Union classifies 165 as hazardous to the health or the environment.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="464ed070-4116-4cc1-beaf-dc8a0b0517b4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="464ed070-4116-4cc1-beaf-dc8a0b0517b4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Environmental impact of the textile and clothing industry</em>, European Parliamentary Research Service, January 2019, europarl.europa.eu.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Microplastics.</em> An average of 700,000 fibers is released in a standard laundry load,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1b45c522-c1a9-4a5b-8f94-17072cf2d6b8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1b45c522-c1a9-4a5b-8f94-17072cf2d6b8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ocean Clean Wash, 2019, oceancleanwash.org.</span></span></span></a></span> and half a million tons of microfibers (which are a type of microplastic) end up in oceans every year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f389649f-0904-4f33-b030-56c3367b6db0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f389649f-0904-4f33-b030-56c3367b6db0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The new plastics economy: Rethinking the future of plastics & catalysing action</em>, Ellen MacArthur Foundation, December 13, 2017, ellenmacarthurfoundation.org.</span></span></span></a></span> An estimated 35 percent of primary microplastics in the world’s oceans originate from the washing of synthetic textiles.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e192fc00-9a2a-4483-83a5-8dcbc5a90a43"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e192fc00-9a2a-4483-83a5-8dcbc5a90a43" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Julian Boucher and Damien Friot, <em>Primary microplastics in the oceans</em>, International Union for Conservation of Nature, 2017, iucn.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Toxic chemicals in synthetic microfibers poison marine wildlife.</li>
    <li><em>Waste. </em>Only 12 percent of textile waste is downcycled (broken down into its component materials), and less than one percent is closed loop recycled. Nearly three-fourths—73 percent—of textile waste is incinerated or ends up in landfills, which release pollutants into their surroundings and contribute to habitat loss.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f31c61c1-4d5a-485f-a9a5-8fac43259e34"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f31c61c1-4d5a-485f-a9a5-8fac43259e34" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“One garbage truck of textiles wasted every second: Report creates vision for change,” Ellen MacArthur Foundation, November 28, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> Anywhere from 30 to 300 species per hectare may be lost during the development of just one landfill site.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2741ca7d-02b5-4311-881b-809f5ec59ded"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2741ca7d-02b5-4311-881b-809f5ec59ded" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The effects of landfills on the environment</em>, Sciencing, April 19, 2018, sciencing.com.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
</ul>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Apparel supply chains are directly linked to soil degradation, conversion of natural ecosystems, and waterway pollution.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>These are sobering statistics. For the apparel sector to slow broader global biodiversity loss, a radical shift from business as usual will be necessary.</p>
<h2>Four intervention areas to focus on</h2>
<p>The good news is that <a href="/featured-insights/leadership/taking-ownership-of-a-sustainable-future">apparel companies have started to pay attention</a> to this issue—and have the power to truly move the needle. While apparel companies can take numerous potential actions that could be relevant and synergistic, each action will come with trade-offs. Based on our analysis, apparel companies would do well to prioritize the following high-impact strategic interventions:</p>
<h3>1. Scale up innovative materials and processes</h3>
<p>There is no perfect material. As discussed, each of the most commonly used materials in the apparel industry—cotton, MMCFs, and synthetics—has a negative impact on biodiversity. But each of these can be made more sustainable. Furthermore, better alternatives do exist and could dramatically improve with more investment and innovation.</p>
<h4>Improve the sustainability of cotton, MMCFs, and synthetics</h4>
<p>The agricultural techniques used to produce raw materials have a significant effect on biodiversity.</p>
<p>Multiple technologies that are already available today—precision agriculture, integrated pest management (IPM), and micro-irrigation—reduce water and chemical intensity to a certain extent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c0493890-7cc0-4f68-bd87-c59b8eb616a7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c0493890-7cc0-4f68-bd87-c59b8eb616a7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Aavudai Anandhi and Narayanan Kannan, <em>Water management for sustainable food production</em>, MDPI, March 11, 2020, mdpi.com.</span></span></span></a></span> A broader shift that includes organic and even regenerative agriculture has the potential to go further. But as we mentioned earlier, there are trade-offs.</p>
<p>Organic cultivation restricts the use of fertilizers and crop-protection chemistries. It’s also, depending on the location, been shown to use up to 90 percent less blue water (the rainfall that enters bodies of water, the main source of water used for irrigation purposes).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4edd416c-6700-4330-b5b5-c786cf7d5f30"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4edd416c-6700-4330-b5b5-c786cf7d5f30" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Textile Exchange, 2019, textileexchange.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Regenerative techniques—both organic and nonorganic—have shown the potential to restore soil micronutrients over time.</p>
<p>Organic-cotton production is unlikely to be realizable at scale and achieve the efficiency of conventional systems.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1504e169-8479-4fe3-8418-c6ad535840b4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1504e169-8479-4fe3-8418-c6ad535840b4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Dionys Forster et al, “Yield and economic performance of organic and conventional cotton-based farming—results from a field trial in India,” <em>Plos One</em>, December 4, 2013, journals.plos.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Currently, its market share is just one percent of the total cotton market.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fd8bba5f-0745-4c6b-9cf6-19f9987a8eb8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fd8bba5f-0745-4c6b-9cf6-19f9987a8eb8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>2025 Sustainable Cotton Challenge</em>, first annual report, Textile Exchange, 2018, textileexchange.org.</span></span></span></a></span> It typically yields 15 to 25 percent lower harvests and has more volatility during the production cycle. What’s more, converting agriculture production systems to organic is challenging, especially for small-scale farms, as the conversion process can take up to three years.</p>
<p>To find a scalable solution, the apparel industry needs to consider how to optimize global cotton production’s environmental footprint. That will require supporting multiple production systems that balance efficiency, environmental stewardship, and farmer needs, which together must also meet the demands of the end customers.</p>
<p>As for MMCFs, many brands are already sourcing them from plantations certified by the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) and Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification (PEFC). And as for synthetics, some brands are reducing their use of fossil-fuel-based synthetics in favor of sustainably sourced natural fibers, recycled PET,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e4f1a806-2dfc-4171-839f-65fbb4e4642a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e4f1a806-2dfc-4171-839f-65fbb4e4642a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Polyethylene terephthalate.</span></span></span></a></span> or biobased synthetics. These alternatives do, however, have limitations. For one, biobased synthetics break down into acid in water, contributing to ocean acidification. Recycled fibers are technically complex to produce. And because MMCFs and synthetics are by-products of other industries (such as the paper and pulp industry or the oil industry), apparel companies have less influence over how these materials are produced.</p>
<h4>Invest in textile innovation</h4>
<p>R&D into material innovation has yielded numerous lower-impact alternatives to conventional fibers. Lyocell, a cellulose fiber made from gum trees, and Spinnova, made from wood pulp and agricultural waste, leverage closed-loop or zero-percent-chemical approaches. Biodegradable polyesters and biopolyesters are made from nonsynthetic natural materials like starch or cellulose. Recycled fibers not only repurpose waste but also have a lower biodiversity footprint than virgin fibers.</p>
<p>Scaling up the commercial availability of these innovative fibers will require investment. Economies of scale should help reduce price points, but these newer materials are likely to remain expensive, used only by sustainability-minded designers. As for recycled fibers, scaling will depend on whether they can be made more robust and less prone to shedding so that they don’t contribute to microplastic pollution, and on whether recycling blend textiles becomes viable.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>In the absence of effective regulation, waterway pollution from textile dyeing and processing requires a tougher stance from apparel brands.</p></blockquote></div>
<h3>2. Take an aggressive stance against waterway pollution</h3>
<p>In the absence of effective regulation, waterway pollution from textile dyeing and processing requires a tougher stance from apparel brands.</p>
<p>Because many suppliers in developing countries lack the resources and knowledge to monitor and track the chemicals they use, brands need to step up and engage with suppliers through education, targeted investment, and stricter accountability to establish basic certification standards at scale. At the very minimum, suppliers should comply with Zero Discharge of Hazardous Chemicals, Manufacturing Restricted Substances List (ZDHC MRSL), and Wastewater Guidelines, which regulate the use of hazardous chemicals and wastewater discharge.</p>
<p>Once standards are in place, brands and suppliers can pursue more high-tech options to reduce nonbiodegradable waste. These include moving from wet processing to waterless dyeing, which uses supercritical carbon dioxide, or to digital printing, which reduces water and chemical dependency. For example, Netherlands-based DyeCoo’s waterless dyeing technology saves 32 million liters of water and 160 tons of processing chemicals a year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="92008130-0d06-458e-9bc7-b707f71af649"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="92008130-0d06-458e-9bc7-b707f71af649" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">BusinessEurope, 2019, businesseurope.eu.</span></span></span></a></span> Advanced wastewater-treatment technologies, such as purifying water through reverse osmosis, are also highly effective, with a recovery rate around 90 percent and the ability to reuse treated wastewater in a closed-loop system.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6d34ec26-1e28-4a69-a0ec-8f702c6c24d5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6d34ec26-1e28-4a69-a0ec-8f702c6c24d5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Peter Hauser, <em>Advances in Treating Textile Effluent</em>, paragraph 2.1.6.1, first edition, Rijeka, Croatia: InTechOpen, 2011.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, apparel companies can switch to “greener” chemicals (such as plant-based instead of mineral-oil-based lubricants) or natural dyes, which generate less effluent.</p>
<p>Most of these technologies are well established. The key hurdle is higher cost. For example, DyeCoo’s waterless dyeing machine runs from $2.5 million to $4 million. Apparel brands need to consider how to work with suppliers and potentially local governments to finance long-term investments in cleaner technologies.</p>
<h3>3. Lead the way in education and empowering consumers</h3>
<p>Brands can help further educate consumers about what they can do to minimize the impact of their actions on biodiversity loss. Simple behavioral adjustments and consumption choices can have substantive results. For example, just doing laundry differently—specifically, in the following three ways—can make a big impact.</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Washing in cold water.</em> Laundering synthetic garments releases microplastics into the water system; the more water used, the more friction happens between clothes and the more microplastics are shed. Changing washing-machine settings from delicate to cold express cycles can reduce microfiber shedding by 57 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="789fcb83-f7f5-4a28-88ac-c79cfc3950fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="789fcb83-f7f5-4a28-88ac-c79cfc3950fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Max R. Kelly et al, “Importance of water-volume on the release of microplastic fibers from laundry,” <em>Environmental Science and Technology</em>, Volume 52, Number 20, August 28, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><em>Filtering microfibers.</em> Consumers can retrofit microfiber filters into their washing machines to prevent microfibers from entering waterways. An even lower-cost solution is to use fiber-collection bags, which are essentially specialized laundry bags that can catch 90 to 99 percent of microfibers before they enter water systems.</li>
    <li><em>Using water-efficient washing machines.</em> Consumers can also pay attention to water efficiency when purchasing a washing machine. On the commercial side, waterless—and nearly waterless—washing machines can save up to 80 percent of water used by traditional machines, plus they limit microplastics shedding.</li>
</ul>
<p>Another way consumers can have a disproportionately positive impact on biodiversity is to get more use out of clothes they already own. Using a piece of clothing nine months longer can reduce its associated CO<sub>2</sub> emissions by 27 percent, its water use by 33 percent, and its waste by 22 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0e67c625-9028-4e17-b4ec-9c23d703ee1f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0e67c625-9028-4e17-b4ec-9c23d703ee1f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Valuing our clothes—The true cost of how we design, use and dispose of clothing in the UK</em>, WRAP, 2012, wrap.org.uk.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In addition, consumers can reduce waste through garment repair, recycling, and resale. Prominent campaigns by retailers like H&M, which accepts any brand’s clothing for recycling, are gaining traction. Brands have extraordinary influence to market such initiatives, ensure they have consumer appeal, and shift consumer mindsets and behaviors.</p>
<p>Besides helping drive consumer awareness, brands can incentivize behavioral change—for example, by offering small vouchers in exchange for used clothing. The industry can further push by providing viable business models for repair and reuse like Patagonia did in 2019, when its Worn Wear Program repaired more than 40,000 pieces of clothing.</p>
<h3>4. Relentlessly pursue zero waste</h3>
<p>One of the most powerful changes the apparel sector can make in the interest of biodiversity is to simply stop making too many clothes. Average overproduction is estimated around 20 percent. Manufacturers recycle roughly 75 percent of preconsumer textile waste. But the remaining 25 percent primarily ends up in landfills or is incinerated—without ever having been worn, though some of it may be donated.</p>
<h2>Demonstrate bold leadership</h2>
<p>The general steps that apparel companies can take to help <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/global-surveys-of-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis">transform sustainability in the industry are well known</a>. But if the industry is to make measurable, significant progress on biodiversity specifically, companies must demonstrate leadership in the following ways:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Manage for biodiversity like you manage value creation.</em> Factor biodiversity impact into financial reporting—for example, through impact-weighted accounts or environmental profit-and-loss approaches—and manage it like financial performance. Commit to forthcoming biodiversity science-based targets to further channel internal sustainability-related investments.</li>
    <li><em>Shift the paradigm <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/time-for-change-how-to-use-the-crisis-to-make-fashion-sourcing-more-agile-and-sustainable">on supplier engagement</a>.</em> Upstream biodiversity interventions are complex and can often have associated costs. Collaborate with other brands to define joint standards for suppliers. The suppliers will benefit from less operational complexity and economies of scale, while brands can push for more stringent specifications rather than dilute them to the lowest common denominator.</li>
    <li><em>Invest in the broader ecosystem to accelerate and scale innovation.</em> Team up with other apparel companies to invest in scaling and industrializing emerging, low-impact technologies and substitutes for nonsynthetic fibers. With a multitude of viable options on the market, the priority should be on focusing investments to establish new dominant materials and processes.</li>
    <li><em>Push for change in adjacent, relevant industries.</em> The apparel sector is closely intertwined with the agricultural, livestock, and chemical industries; all face similar challenges in addressing their biodiversity footprints. Pushing for closer cross-industry collaboration through working groups and roundtables will be mutually beneficial to all participants.</li>
    <li><em>Engage with policy makers and welcome regulations.</em> Be proactive in engaging on meaningful biodiversity regulation. Existing regulations such as the EU Single-Use Plastics Directive or Extended Producer Responsibility schemes (for product disposal/recycling) have helped make sustainability a shared responsibility.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>We expect biodiversity to become <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/the-influence-of-woke-consumers-on-fashion">an even greater concern for consumers and investors</a> in the coming years. COVID-19, instead of slowing the trend, has accelerated it—perhaps because people now understand more deeply that human and animal ecosystems are interdependent. It’s time for the apparel industry, which to date has contributed heavily to biodiversity loss, to now make bold moves in the opposite direction.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/anna-granskog">Anna Granskog</a></strong> is a partner in McKinsey’s Helsinki office; <strong><a href="/our-people/franck-laizet">Franck Laizet</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Paris office; <strong><a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b1de75077-5b46-412e-bfeb-2309c9c08f92%7d%40en">Miriam Lobis</a></strong> is a partner in the Berlin office; and <strong>Corinne Sawers</strong> is an associate partner in the London office.</p>

Here are four interventions that can make the biggest impact."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"The apparel industry can radically reduce its contribution to biodiversity loss through four strategic interventions."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-07-23T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEven amid the COVID-19 pandemic,\u003c/strong\u003e sustainability remains top of mind for consumers, investors, and regulators\u0026mdash;in fact, engagement in sustainability has deepened during the crisis. For example, two-thirds of apparel shoppers say that limiting impact on climate change is now more important to them since before COVID-19.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eBut while much has been written about \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/survey-consumer-sentiment-on-sustainability-in-fashion\"\u003ethe fashion industry\u0026rsquo;s impact on climate change\u003c/a\u003e, less well known and well covered is the industry\u0026rsquo;s heavy footprint on biodiversity. Broadly defined as the variety of all life forms on earth, biodiversity matters. We rely on it for food and energy, and we depend on its irreplaceable role in sustaining air quality, providing fresh water and soil, and regulating climate. And yet biodiversity is declining at a faster rate than ever before in human history.[[footnote 2]] One million species, between 12 percent and 20 percent of estimated total species, marine and terrestrial alike, are under threat of extinction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe apparel industry is a significant contributor to biodiversity loss. Apparel supply chains are directly linked to soil degradation, conversion of natural ecosystems, and waterway pollution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article examines the apparel industry\u0026rsquo;s largest contributors to biodiversity loss, how companies can strategically mitigate that loss, and what brands can do to boldly lead the industry\u0026rsquo;s biodiversity efforts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eApparel\u0026rsquo;s contribution to biodiversity loss\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor several years now, apparel companies have been active in the fight against climate change, launching myriad initiatives to become carbon neutral. Biodiversity is a distinct but related issue. Biodiversity loss and climate change are interdependent and mutually reinforcing\u0026mdash;one accelerates the other, and vice versa. For example, protecting forests could help reduce greenhouse-gas emissions. In turn, the rise of global temperatures increases the risk of species extinction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause biodiversity is such a complex and multidimensional landscape, and ecosystem degradation is so wide ranging\u0026mdash;affecting oceans, freshwater, soil, and forests\u0026mdash;multiple metrics and indicators are needed to measure impact and progress. Setting targets and accountability for such a complex range is much more challenging than managing for the single metric of greenhouse emissions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThrough our analysis of quantitative impact indicators as well as industry-expert interviews, we have developed a good understanding of how each part of the apparel value chain affects biodiversity. Most of the negative impact comes from three stages in the \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/what-radical-transparency-could-mean-for-the-fashion-industry\"\u003evalue chain\u003c/a\u003e: raw-material production, material preparation and processing, and end of life (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe also have developed a map of biodiversity impact areas to help companies determine where to focus their efforts (Exhibit 2).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eBased on our analysis, we have identified the apparel sector\u0026rsquo;s five largest contributors to biodiversity loss. They are presented according to the fashion value chain, not by magnitude of impact:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCotton agriculture.\u003c/em\u003e Cotton is the most used nonsynthetic fiber in the world. Farming it is especially insecticide and pesticide intensive: although cotton grows on only 2.4 percent of global cropland, it accounts for 22.5 percent of the world\u0026rsquo;s insecticide use\u0026mdash;more than any other single crop\u0026mdash;and 10 percent of all pesticide use. Cotton is also a water-intensive crop; some estimates suggest that 713 gallons (2,700 liters) of water are needed to produce one T-shirt.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWood-based natural fibers/man-made cellulose fibers (MMCFs).\u003c/em\u003e MMCFs are created from cellulose, mainly derived from wood. According to estimates, more than 150 million trees are logged annually for MMCFs.[[footnote 4]] While the majority of MMCFs come from tree plantations that are certified and sustainable, up to 30 percent of MMCFs may come from endangered and primary forests.[[footnote 5]] Furthermore, water and soil pollution from chemicals used in plantation forests and during pulp processing drive habitat loss and endanger species, unless the process is 100 percent closed loop.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTextile dyeing and treatment.\u003c/em\u003e Approximately 25 percent of industrial water pollution comes from textile dyeing and treatment. These processes overexploit freshwater resources and contaminate waterways through chemical runoff and nonbiodegradable liquid waste. Of the 1,900 chemicals used in clothing production, the European Union classifies 165 as hazardous to the health or the environment.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMicroplastics.\u003c/em\u003e An average of 700,000 fibers is released in a standard laundry load,[[footnote 7]] and half a million tons of microfibers (which are a type of microplastic) end up in oceans every year.[[footnote 8]] An estimated 35 percent of primary microplastics in the world\u0026rsquo;s oceans originate from the washing of synthetic textiles.[[footnote 9]] Toxic chemicals in synthetic microfibers poison marine wildlife.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWaste.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003eOnly 12 percent of textile waste is downcycled (broken down into its component materials), and less than one percent is closed loop recycled. Nearly three-fourths\u0026mdash;73 percent\u0026mdash;of textile waste is incinerated or ends up in landfills, which release pollutants into their surroundings and contribute to habitat loss.[[footnote 10]] Anywhere from 30 to 300 species per hectare may be lost during the development of just one landfill site.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThese are sobering statistics. For the apparel sector to slow broader global biodiversity loss, a radical shift from business as usual will be necessary.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFour intervention areas to focus on\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe good news is that \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/leadership/taking-ownership-of-a-sustainable-future\"\u003eapparel companies have started to pay attention\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to this issue\u0026mdash;and have the power to truly move the needle. While apparel companies can take numerous potential actions that could be relevant and synergistic, each action will come with trade-offs. Based on our analysis, apparel companies would do well to prioritize the following high-impact strategic interventions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e1. Scale up innovative materials and processes\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere is no perfect material. As discussed, each of the most commonly used materials in the apparel industry\u0026mdash;cotton, MMCFs, and synthetics\u0026mdash;has a negative impact on biodiversity. But each of these can be made more sustainable. Furthermore, better alternatives do exist and could dramatically improve with more investment and innovation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eImprove the sustainability of cotton, MMCFs, and synthetics\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe agricultural techniques used to produce raw materials have a significant effect on biodiversity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMultiple technologies that are already available today\u0026mdash;precision agriculture, integrated pest management (IPM), and micro-irrigation\u0026mdash;reduce water and chemical intensity to a certain extent.[[footnote 12]] A broader shift that includes organic and even regenerative agriculture has the potential to go further. But as we mentioned earlier, there are trade-offs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOrganic cultivation restricts the use of fertilizers and crop-protection chemistries. It\u0026rsquo;s also, depending on the location, been shown to use up to 90 percent less blue water (the rainfall that enters bodies of water, the main source of water used for irrigation purposes).[[footnote 13]] Regenerative techniques\u0026mdash;both organic and nonorganic\u0026mdash;have shown the potential to restore soil micronutrients over time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOrganic-cotton production is unlikely to be realizable at scale and achieve the efficiency of conventional systems.[[footnote 14]] Currently, its market share is just one percent of the total cotton market.[[footnote 15]] It typically yields 15 to 25 percent lower harvests and has more volatility during the production cycle. What\u0026rsquo;s more, converting agriculture production systems to organic is challenging, especially for small-scale farms, as the conversion process can take up to three years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo find a scalable solution, the apparel industry needs to consider how to optimize global cotton production\u0026rsquo;s environmental footprint. That will require supporting multiple production systems that balance efficiency, environmental stewardship, and farmer needs, which together must also meet the demands of the end customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs for MMCFs, many brands are already sourcing them from plantations certified by the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) and Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification (PEFC). And as for synthetics, some brands are reducing their use of fossil-fuel-based synthetics in favor of sustainably sourced natural fibers, recycled PET,[[footnote 16]] or biobased synthetics. These alternatives do, however, have limitations. For one, biobased synthetics break down into acid in water, contributing to ocean acidification. Recycled fibers are technically complex to produce. And because MMCFs and synthetics are by-products of other industries (such as the paper and pulp industry or the oil industry), apparel companies have less influence over how these materials are produced.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eInvest in textile innovation\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eR\u0026amp;D into material innovation has yielded numerous lower-impact alternatives to conventional fibers. Lyocell, a cellulose fiber made from gum trees, and Spinnova, made from wood pulp and agricultural waste, leverage closed-loop or zero-percent-chemical approaches. Biodegradable polyesters and biopolyesters are made from nonsynthetic natural materials like starch or cellulose. Recycled fibers not only repurpose waste but also have a lower biodiversity footprint than virgin fibers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eScaling up the commercial availability of these innovative fibers will require investment. Economies of scale should help reduce price points, but these newer materials are likely to remain expensive, used only by sustainability-minded designers. As for recycled fibers, scaling will depend on whether they can be made more robust and less prone to shedding so that they don\u0026rsquo;t contribute to microplastic pollution, and on whether recycling blend textiles becomes viable.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003ch3\u003e2. Take an aggressive stance against waterway pollution\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the absence of effective regulation, waterway pollution from textile dyeing and processing requires a tougher stance from apparel brands.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBecause many suppliers in developing countries lack the resources and knowledge to monitor and track the chemicals they use, brands need to step up and engage with suppliers through education, targeted investment, and stricter accountability to establish basic certification standards at scale. At the very minimum, suppliers should comply with Zero Discharge of Hazardous Chemicals, Manufacturing Restricted Substances List (ZDHC MRSL), and Wastewater Guidelines, which regulate the use of hazardous chemicals and wastewater discharge.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce standards are in place, brands and suppliers can pursue more high-tech options to reduce nonbiodegradable waste. These include moving from wet processing to waterless dyeing, which uses supercritical carbon dioxide, or to digital printing, which reduces water and chemical dependency. For example, Netherlands-based DyeCoo\u0026rsquo;s waterless dyeing technology saves 32 million liters of water and 160 tons of processing chemicals a year.[[footnote 17]] Advanced wastewater-treatment technologies, such as purifying water through reverse osmosis, are also highly effective, with a recovery rate around 90 percent and the ability to reuse treated wastewater in a closed-loop system.[[footnote 18]] In addition, apparel companies can switch to \u0026ldquo;greener\u0026rdquo; chemicals (such as plant-based instead of mineral-oil-based lubricants) or natural dyes, which generate less effluent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost of these technologies are well established. The key hurdle is higher cost. For example, DyeCoo\u0026rsquo;s waterless dyeing machine runs from $2.5 million to $4 million. Apparel brands need to consider how to work with suppliers and potentially local governments to finance long-term investments in cleaner technologies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e3. Lead the way in education and empowering consumers\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBrands can help further educate consumers about what they can do to minimize the impact of their actions on biodiversity loss. Simple behavioral adjustments and consumption choices can have substantive results. For example, just doing laundry differently\u0026mdash;specifically, in the following three ways\u0026mdash;can make a big impact.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eWashing in cold water.\u003c/em\u003e Laundering synthetic garments releases microplastics into the water system; the more water used, the more friction happens between clothes and the more microplastics are shed. Changing washing-machine settings from delicate to cold express cycles can reduce microfiber shedding by 57 percent.[[footnote 19]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFiltering microfibers.\u003c/em\u003e Consumers can retrofit microfiber filters into their washing machines to prevent microfibers from entering waterways. An even lower-cost solution is to use fiber-collection bags, which are essentially specialized laundry bags that can catch 90 to 99 percent of microfibers before they enter water systems.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUsing water-efficient washing machines.\u003c/em\u003e Consumers can also pay attention to water efficiency when purchasing a washing machine. On the commercial side, waterless\u0026mdash;and nearly waterless\u0026mdash;washing machines can save up to 80 percent of water used by traditional machines, plus they limit microplastics shedding.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother way consumers can have a disproportionately positive impact on biodiversity is to get more use out of clothes they already own. Using a piece of clothing nine months longer can reduce its associated CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions by 27 percent, its water use by 33 percent, and its waste by 22 percent.[[footnote 20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition, consumers can reduce waste through garment repair, recycling, and resale. Prominent campaigns by retailers like H\u0026amp;M, which accepts any brand\u0026rsquo;s clothing for recycling, are gaining traction. Brands have extraordinary influence to market such initiatives, ensure they have consumer appeal, and shift consumer mindsets and behaviors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBesides helping drive consumer awareness, brands can incentivize behavioral change\u0026mdash;for example, by offering small vouchers in exchange for used clothing. The industry can further push by providing viable business models for repair and reuse like Patagonia did in 2019, when its Worn Wear Program repaired more than 40,000 pieces of clothing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e4. Relentlessly pursue zero waste\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne of the most powerful changes the apparel sector can make in the interest of biodiversity is to simply stop making too many clothes. Average overproduction is estimated around 20 percent. Manufacturers recycle roughly 75 percent of preconsumer textile waste. But the remaining 25 percent primarily ends up in landfills or is incinerated\u0026mdash;without ever having been worn, though some of it may be donated.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eDemonstrate bold leadership\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe general steps that apparel companies can take to help \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/global-surveys-of-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003etransform sustainability in the industry are well known\u003c/a\u003e. But if the industry is to make measurable, significant progress on biodiversity specifically, companies must demonstrate leadership in the following ways:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eManage for biodiversity like you manage value creation.\u003c/em\u003e Factor biodiversity impact into financial reporting\u0026mdash;for example, through impact-weighted accounts or environmental profit-and-loss approaches\u0026mdash;and manage it like financial performance. Commit to forthcoming biodiversity science-based targets to further channel internal sustainability-related investments.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eShift the paradigm \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/time-for-change-how-to-use-the-crisis-to-make-fashion-sourcing-more-agile-and-sustainable\"\u003eon supplier engagement\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e Upstream biodiversity interventions are complex and can often have associated costs. Collaborate with other brands to define joint standards for suppliers. The suppliers will benefit from less operational complexity and economies of scale, while brands can push for more stringent specifications rather than dilute them to the lowest common denominator.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInvest in the broader ecosystem to accelerate and scale innovation.\u003c/em\u003e Team up with other apparel companies to invest in scaling and industrializing emerging, low-impact technologies and substitutes for nonsynthetic fibers. With a multitude of viable options on the market, the priority should be on focusing investments to establish new dominant materials and processes.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePush for change in adjacent, relevant industries.\u003c/em\u003e The apparel sector is closely intertwined with the agricultural, livestock, and chemical industries; all face similar challenges in addressing their biodiversity footprints. Pushing for closer cross-industry collaboration through working groups and roundtables will be mutually beneficial to all participants.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEngage with policy makers and welcome regulations.\u003c/em\u003e Be proactive in engaging on meaningful biodiversity regulation. Existing regulations such as the EU Single-Use Plastics Directive or Extended Producer Responsibility schemes (for product disposal/recycling) have helped make sustainability a shared responsibility.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe expect biodiversity to become \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/the-influence-of-woke-consumers-on-fashion\"\u003ean even greater concern for consumers and investors\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the coming years. COVID-19, instead of slowing the trend, has accelerated it\u0026mdash;perhaps because people now understand more deeply that human and animal ecosystems are interdependent. It\u0026rsquo;s time for the apparel industry, which to date has contributed heavily to biodiversity loss, to now make bold moves in the opposite direction.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2020-07-23T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Consumer sentiment on sustainability and fashion in the COVID crisis,\u0026rdquo;
